publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-1193 Mr Keith Harding: Local Government Strike Action—That the Parliament expresses its concern over the continued strike action due to a dispute over pay affecting local government services and notes that enough money would be available to meet wage demands if Her Majesty’s Government had not abolished advance corporation tax credit for pension funds in July 1997, a change which is costing Scottish councils £20.5 million each year, and if Scottish local authorities were to improve their council tax collection rates so that they were on a par with their counterparts south of the border, which would generate an extra £70 million each year.
S1M-1193 Local Government Strike Action (lodged on 19 September 2000) Mr Brian Monteith*, Mrs Lyndsay McIntosh*, Alex Johnstone*

S1M-1193 Mr Keith Harding: Local Government Strike Action—That the Parliament expresses its concern over the continued strike action due to a dispute over pay affecting local government services and notes that enough money would be available to meet wage demands if Her Majesty’s Government had not abolished advance corporation tax credit for pension funds in July 1997, a change which is costing Scottish councils £20.5 million each year, and if Scottish local authorities were to improve their council tax collection rates so that they were on a par with their counterparts south of the border, which would generate an extra £70 million each year. Supported by: Mr Brian Monteith, Mrs Lyndsay McIntosh, Alex Johnstone, Mr Murray Tosh*
S1M-1193 Local Government Strike Action (lodged on 19 September 2000) Phil Gallie*
S1M-1193 Local Government Strike Action (lodged on 19 September 2000) Alex Fergusson*
S1M-1193 Local Government Strike Action (lodged on 19 September 2000) David McLetchie*, Mr Jamie McGrigor*, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton*
S1M-1193 Local Government Strike Action (lodged on 19 September 2000) John Scott*

S1M-1193 Mr Keith Harding: Local Government Strike Action—That the Parliament expresses its concern over the continued strike action due to a dispute over pay affecting local government services and notes that enough money would be available to meet wage demands if Her Majesty’s Government had not abolished advance corporation tax credit for pension funds in July 1997, a change which is costing Scottish councils £20.5 million each year, and if Scottish local authorities were to improve their council tax collection rates so that they were on a par with their counterparts south of the border, which would generate an extra £70 million each year. Supported by: Mr Brian Monteith, Mrs Lyndsay McIntosh, Alex Johnstone, Mr Murray Tosh, Phil Gallie, Alex Fergusson, David McLetchie, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, John Scott, Nick Johnston*

S1M-1193 Mr Keith Harding: Local Government Strike Action—That the Parliament expresses its concern over the continued strike action due to a dispute over pay affecting local government services and notes that enough money would be available to meet wage demands if Her Majesty’s Government had not abolished advance corporation tax credit for pension funds in July 1997, a change which is costing Scottish councils £20.5 million each year, and if Scottish local authorities were to improve their council tax collection rates so that they were on a par with their counterparts south of the border, which would generate an extra £70 million each year. Supported by: Mr Brian Monteith, Mrs Lyndsay McIntosh, Alex Johnstone, Mr Murray Tosh, Phil Gallie, Alex Fergusson, David McLetchie, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, John Scott, Nick Johnston

S1M-1193 Local Government Strike Action (lodged on 19 September 2000) Mary Scanlon*

S1M-1193 Mr Keith Harding: Local Government Strike Action—That the Parliament expresses its concern over the continued strike action due to a dispute over pay affecting local government services and notes that enough money would be available to meet wage demands if Her Majesty’s Government had not abolished advance corporation tax credit for pension funds in July 1997, a change which is costing Scottish councils £20.5 million each year, and if Scottish local authorities were to improve their council tax collection rates so that they were on a par with their counterparts south of the border, which would generate an extra £70 million each year.
